ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course does not go beyond basic climate science and policy.
I learned a lot and the class was a pleasure. I would recommend it to others.
This class was a great summary of different concepts on Climate Change. It was very practical, and student led.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: It's a great concept for a class.

this course provided the students with the opportunity to practice presentation skills. It was also a platform to practice debating climate change policy and science. The format of the class was a great strenght for the learning experience.
It was very informative and laid-back.
Students could pick a topic of their interest and then present their research.It was great to have Professor Mendelsohn. He is very knowledgeable on every topic we covered.
The weekly focus on topics, the pro vs. con nature of debates

- The instructor: Professor Mendelsohn is extremely knowledgable and responsive. He is open for teaching but also learning from students and the class turns out to be an interesting discussion with a very admirable scientist.- The class' style: with not much workload, this class was perfect to learn from the discussions and readings, and not studying for an exam

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Professor needs to prepare a little more to make this worth our while (i.e., not just jot down a few quick thoughts in the minutes before class starts). When he did have points to make, it was usually very interesting and insightful.The class also would have been better if we actually debated the issues. As it happened, there were no incentives to do anything other than long and boring presentations.
I would assign a rating scale for the debate to make it more interactive for the non-presenting students.
Maybe some additional overview material for people with less of a science background.
Maybe a bit more of structure would be good.
Large enough class to ensure every topic gets a pro and a con

Organization is definitely an aspect that could improve. The class is rich because of the discussions, and sometimes we did not have both sides of the theme (cons and pros) because schedule was not organized in advance.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
There wasn't any distinction between course lectures and discussions.
N.A.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course encompasses the science and policy of climate change with intensive feedback from an economist point of view. It fits well with my environmental policy specialization area because both the science and economics of climate change are put into debate.

I'm not an FES student but did want to take this course because I think that a basic understanding of climate change is necessary when thinking about global policy implications (my degree is International Relations).
Climate change is not my training focus, so this course was a perfect refresh and a great moment to discuss the main related controversial issues.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Wanted to study climate change issues rigorously and really understand them.
I was very interested in taking a debate-type seminar in climate change. Prof. Mendelsohn is a great lecturer for this kind of class setting.
I wanted to improve my understanding of the policy process regarding the climate change.
I wanted to better understand climate change.
Because it would refresh all the Climate Change concepts I have learned throughout the Master's programme.
Focus on climate change
See Question 17.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No, we didn't go beyond the basics.
Yes. I have an overall knowledge of the basic hot issues in the climate change policy world. I would consider that I can engage in discussion with a solid foundation of science and economy.
Yes, very much so.
Yes.
Yes, the course exceeded them.
Yes! See Question 17.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
N.A.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it if you want an extremely easy class with very little work required.

I would advise that they select topics they aren't experts on. If they are willing to debate something they are not very knowledgeable they would learn even more about why that topic is still unresolved in the climate change world.
It's a really helpful and enjoyable course.
To make sure they pick a topic for the presentations that is of their interest
Come prepared with a strong background in climate issues
Don't take it.

This course is made from discussions among students, and Professor Mendelsohn. So do your readings and/or be responsive and active in class! By doing this, you will be able to touch and get some knowledge on the main issues related to climate change.
